text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GU3eFDU1kgk/VZQhwJzO9_I/AAAAAAAA7DA/670Pleni9hg/s1600/imag734es.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"203\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GU3eFDU1kgk/VZQhwJzO9_I/AAAAAAAA7DA/670Pleni9hg/s400/imag734es.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emotions start and\nfinish arguments. Emotions drive actions. Emotions spark wars and conflict..\nEmotional hungers drive us to satisfy our needs and wants.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Firn__CPC6c/VZQjb5kOUZI/AAAAAAAA7DQ/C0QOJ9LxFKM/s1600/imagyges.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Firn__CPC6c/VZQjb5kOUZI/AAAAAAAA7DQ/C0QOJ9LxFKM/s400/imagyges.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emotions are the\nessence of how we feel about ourselves and our lives. Emotions often tip us to\nact one way or another.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6i4X2jaBYis/VZQi5Eyna3I/AAAAAAAA7DI/J6quHqBNyRw/s1600/dowcnload%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"203\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6i4X2jaBYis/VZQi5Eyna3I/AAAAAAAA7DI/J6quHqBNyRw/s400/dowcnload%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emotional appeals,\nexpressive language, telling stories, description, are all powerful tools in\nhelping others experience what you or someone else has experienced. &nbsp;&nbsp;Descriptive, graphic narrative can\neffectively be used to persuade an audience to your point of view. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-nRjyPA510_Q/VZQkGstkGCI/AAAAAAAA7DY/HsWYW9SrN8c/s1600/imag95es.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"323\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-nRjyPA510_Q/VZQkGstkGCI/AAAAAAAA7DY/HsWYW9SrN8c/s400/imag95es.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, pathos without reason can lead a\nreader to think with his heart and not his head.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-4ivR8spa-7o/VZQknS_XqGI/AAAAAAAA7Dg/Ml-MoLGbiL0/s1600/i9m5mages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-4ivR8spa-7o/VZQknS_XqGI/AAAAAAAA7Dg/Ml-MoLGbiL0/s1600/i9m5mages.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">People just love to\nhear a good story and cannot resist getting carried away by it. It is in\nprecisely this moment that you have the possibility to introduce a suggestion\nin your speech as, being enthralled by the story line, rational defenses are\nmore easily bypassed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-sTkvRvTXL0M/VZQk4ptwLkI/AAAAAAAA7Do/kh3ltrKw0Q4/s1600/im4dzages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"272\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-sTkvRvTXL0M/VZQk4ptwLkI/AAAAAAAA7Do/kh3ltrKw0Q4/s400/im4dzages.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">People can sometimes be\nconvinced by arguments that tug on their heart strings.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1iPR-JvjDDo/VZQlwC9TZQI/AAAAAAAA7D4/gLk8LNB3xSk/s1600/imag69hes.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-1iPR-JvjDDo/VZQlwC9TZQI/AAAAAAAA7D4/gLk8LNB3xSk/s400/imag69hes.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Pathos is usually\nrendered in the form of a narrative or personal anecdote to bring gravity to a\nsituation or make the audience relate to the argument in a personal way.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-UUdhmhJlm-g/VZQlYHHAhgI/AAAAAAAA7Dw/oI6gnZ_9tuU/s1600/images59r.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-UUdhmhJlm-g/VZQlYHHAhgI/AAAAAAAA7Dw/oI6gnZ_9tuU/s400/images59r.jpg\" width=\"302\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">The Rhetoric was\ndeveloped by Aristotle during two periods when he was in Athens, the first,\nfrom 367 to 347 BC (when he was seconded to Plato in the Academy), and the\nsecond, from 335 to 322 BC (when he was running his own school, the Lyceum)<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-NKCv-Qgavsg/VZQnVrHN39I/AAAAAAAA7EU/Yp5LkQemYKg/s1600/yourheartsh95wish.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-NKCv-Qgavsg/VZQnVrHN39I/AAAAAAAA7EU/Yp5LkQemYKg/s400/yourheartsh95wish.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">The Rhetoric consists\nof three books. Book I offers a general overview, presenting the purposes of\nrhetoric and a working definition; it also offers a detailed discussion of the\nmajor contexts and types of rhetoric.&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Book II discusses in detail the three\nmeans of persuasion that an orator must rely on: those grounded in credibility\n(ethos), in the emotions and psychology of the audience (pathos), and in\npatterns of reasoning (logos).&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Book III introduces the elements of style (word\nchoice, metaphor, and sentence structure) and arrangement (organization). Some attention\nis paid to delivery, but generally the reader is referred to the Poetics for\nmore information in that area.[19]<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Many chapters in Book I\nof Aristotle's Rhetoric cover the various typical deliberative arguments in\nAthenian culture.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter One <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle first defines\nrhetoric as the counterpart (antistrophos) of dialectic (Bk. 1:1:1-2). He\nexplains the similarities between the two but fails to comment on the\ndifferences. Here he introduces the term enthymeme (Bk. 1:1:3).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Two <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle's famous\ndefinition of rhetoric is viewed as the ability in any particular case to see\nthe available means of persuasion. He defines pisteis as atechnic (inartistic)\nand entechnic (artistic). Of the pisteis provided through speech there are\nthree parts: ethos, pathos, and logos. He introduces paradigms and syllogisms\nas means of persuasion.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Three <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Introduces the three\ngenres of rhetoric: deliberative, forensic, and epideictic rhetoric. Here he\nalso touches on the \u201cends\" the orators of each of these genres hope to\nreach with their persuasions \u2013 which are discussed in further detail in later\nchapters (Bk. 1:3:5-7). Aristotle introduces these three genres by saying,\n\"The kinds of rhetoric are three in number, corresponding to the three\nkinds of hearers.\" [20][21]<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Four <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle discusses the\ntypes of political topics of deliberative rhetoric. The five most common are\nfinance, war and peace, national defense, imports and exports, and the framing\nof laws.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Five <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle discusses the\ndifferent ethical topics of deliberative rhetoric. Aristotle identifies the\ngoal of human action with \u201chappiness\" and describes the many factors\ncontributing to it (Bk. 1:5:5-18).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Six <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">This is a continuation\nof Chapter Five, explaining in greater detail the stoikhea (elements) of the\n\u201cgood\" described in the previous chapter.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Seven <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Introduces the term\nkoinon[disambiguation needed] of degree. Discusses the 'ends' of deliberative\nrhetoric in relation to the greater good or more advantageous.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Eight <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle defines and\ndiscusses the four forms of politeia (constitution) useful in deliberative\nrhetoric: democracy, oligarchy, aristocracy, and monarchy.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/--ZIPjv02D-c/VZQnnmsDs-I/AAAAAAAA7Ec/q4y5_dBpG-I/s1600/people-donth-buy-for-logical-reasons-they-buy-for-emotional-reasons-quote-1.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/--ZIPjv02D-c/VZQnnmsDs-I/AAAAAAAA7Ec/q4y5_dBpG-I/s400/people-donth-buy-for-logical-reasons-they-buy-for-emotional-reasons-quote-1.jpg\" width=\"302\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Nine <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">This chapter discusses\nthe virtues and concepts of to kalon (the honorable) included in epideictic\nrhetoric. Aristotle describes what makes certain topics appropriate or worthy\nfor praise or blame. He also states that it is important to highlight certain\ntraits of the subject of praise.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Ten <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Discusses what\nsyllogisms should be derived from kategoria (accusations) and apologia\n(defenses) for judicial rhetoric. Also introduces the wrongdoing, which is\nuseful for judicial rhetoric.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Eleven <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">This chapter discusses\nthe many different types of hedone (pleasure) useful for judicial rhetoric.\nAristotle states these as the reasons for people doing wrong.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Twelve <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">This chapter, also\nabout judicial rhetoric, discusses people's dispositions of mind and whom\npeople wrong from the hedone discussed in the previous chapter. Aristotle\nemphasizes the importance of willingness, or intentions, of wrongdoings.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Thirteen <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle classifies\nall acts that are just and unjust defined in judicial rhetoric. He also\ndistinguishes what kinds of actions are fair and unfair with being just.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Fourteen <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">This chapter parallels\nthe koinon described in Chapter Seven. Aristotle is clarifying the magnitude in\nrelation to questions of \u201cwrongdoing\" meant for judicial rhetoric.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter Fifteen <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle summarises\nthe arguments available to a speaker in dealing with evidence that supports or\nweakens a case. These atechnic pisteis contain laws, witnesses, contracts,\ntortures, and oaths.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Overview of Book\nII[edit]<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Book II of Aristotle\u2019s\nRhetoric generally concentrates on ethos and pathos, and as noted by Aristotle,\nboth affect judgment. Specifically, Aristotle refers to the effect of ethos and\npathos on an audience since a speaker needs to exhibit these modes of\npersuasion before that audience.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 1: Introduction<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">In Chapter 1, Aristotle\nnotes that emotions cause men to change their opinion in regard to their\njudgments. As such, emotions have specific causes and effects (Book 2.1.2-3).\nThus, a speaker can employ his understanding as a stimulus for the sought\nemotion from an audience. However, Aristotle states that along with pathos, the\nspeaker must also exhibit ethos, which for Aristotle encompasses wisdom\n(phronesis), virtue (arete), and good will (eunoia) (Book 2.1.5-9).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapters 2-11: Efficacious\nEmotions for Speakers in All Genres of Rhetoric<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapters 2-11 explore\nthose emotions useful to a rhetorical speaker. Aristotle provides an account on\nhow to arouse these emotions in an audience so that a speaker might be able to\nproduce the desired action successfully (Book 2.2.27).&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle arranges the\ndiscussion of the emotions in opposing pairs, such as anger and calmness or\nfriendliness and enmity. For each emotion, Aristotle discusses the person\u2019s\nstate of mind, against whom one directs the emotion, and for what reasons (Book\n2.1.9). It is pertinent to understand all the components in order to stimulate\na certain emotion within another person.&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">For example, to Aristotle, anger\nresults from the feeling of belittlement (Book 2.2.3-4). Those who become angry\nare in a state of distress due to a foiling of their desires (Book 2.2.9). The\nangry direct their emotion towards those who insult the latter or that which\nthe latter values. These insults are the reasoning behind the anger (Book\n2.2.12-27).&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">In this way, Aristotle proceeds to define each emotion, assess the\nstate of mind for those experiencing the emotion, determine to whom people\ndirect the emotion, and reveal their reasoning behind the emotion. The\nsignificance of Aristotle\u2019s analysis stems from his idea that emotions have\nlogical grounding and material sources.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapters 12-17: Ethos:\nAdapting the Character of the Speech to the Character of the Audience<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Book III of Aristotle\u2019s\nRhetoric is often overshadowed by the first two books. While Books I and II are\nmore systematic and address ethos, logos, and pathos, Book III is often\nconsidered a conglomeration of Greek stylistic devices on rhetoric. However,\nBook III contains informative material on lexis (style) which refers to the\n\u201cway of saying\" (in Chapters 1-12) and taxis, which refers to the\narrangement of words (in Chapters 13-19).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QWPEt8Yzg-o/VZQnCBbNH2I/AAAAAAAA7EM/Mlp9Nose3FU/s1600/genius-is-the-ability-gto-renew-ones-emotions-in-daily-experience-paul-cezanne.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"412\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QWPEt8Yzg-o/VZQnCBbNH2I/AAAAAAAA7EM/Mlp9Nose3FU/s640/genius-is-the-ability-gto-renew-ones-emotions-in-daily-experience-paul-cezanne.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapters 1\u201312: Style\n(lexis)<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 1 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Summarizes Aristotle's\nBook I and Book II and introduces the term hypokrisis (pronuntiatio). Aristotle\nargues that voice should be used to most accurately represent the given\nsituation as exemplified by poets (Bk. 3 1:3-4).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 2 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Highlights ar\u00eate, which\nis defined as virtue or excellence. When applied to rhetoric, ar\u00eate means\nnatural rather than forced or artificial (Bk. 3 2:1-4). Metaphors are also\naddressed as a skill that cannot be taught and should bestow \u201cverbal\nbeauty\" (Bk. 3 2:6-13).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 3 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Deals with\n\"frigid\" language. This occurs when one uses elaborate double words,\narchaic, and rare words, added descriptive words or phrases, and inappropriate\nmetaphors (Bk. 3 3:1-4).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 4 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Discusses another\nfigurative part of speech, the simile (also known as an eikon). Similes are\nonly occasionally useful in speech due to their poetic nature and similarity to\nmetaphor.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 5 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Addresses how to speak\nproperly by using connectives, calling things by their specific name, avoiding\nterms with ambiguous meanings, observing the gender of nouns, and correctly\nusing singular and plural words (Bk. 3 5:1-6).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 6 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Gives practical advice\non how to amplify language by using Onkos (expansiveness) and syntomia\n(conciseness). Not using the term circle, but giving its definition, would\nexemplify onkos, and using the word as the definition would exemplify syntomia\n(Bk.3 5:1-3).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 7 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle expands on\nthe use of appropriate style in addressing the subject. \"Lexis will be\nappropriate if it expresses emotion and character and is proportional to the\nsubject matter\". Aristotle stresses emotion, credibility, genus (like\nage), and moral state as important considerations (Bk. 3 7:1-6).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-J5fVYL2pLDk/VZ2HLnK1-mI/AAAAAAAA7Ho/f0N7V9NamXY/s1600/do5wnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"187\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-J5fVYL2pLDk/VZ2HLnK1-mI/AAAAAAAA7Ho/f0N7V9NamXY/s400/do5wnload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 8 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Rhythm should be\nincorporated into prose to make it well \"rhythmed\" but not to the\nextent of a poem (Bk.3 8:3-7).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 9 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Looks at periodic style\nand how it should be seen as a rhythmical unit and used to complete a thought\nto help understand meaning (Bk.3 9:3-4).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 10 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle further\nhighlights the metaphor and addresses how it brings about learning and enables\nvisualization (Bk. 3 10:1-6).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 11 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Explains why devices of\nstyle can defamiliarize language. Aristotle warns that it is inappropriate to\nspeak in hyperbole (Bk. 3 11:15).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 12 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">The three genres of\noral and written language are deliberative, judicial, and epideictic, all of\nwhich are written by logographoi (speech writers) who are each skilled at\ndifferent types of speeches. This transitions into the next section of chapters\non taxis.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5hlYxfLam1w/VZ2HAGnYU_I/AAAAAAAA7Hg/rM4orZT5EV0/s1600/downlroad.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"203\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5hlYxfLam1w/VZ2HAGnYU_I/AAAAAAAA7Hg/rM4orZT5EV0/s400/downlroad.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapters 13\u201319:\nTaxis<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 13 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Covers the necessary\nparts of a speech which include the prosthesis (which is the statement of the\nproposition) and then the pistis (which is the proof of the statement), along\nwith the prooemium (introduction) and epilogue (Bk.3 13:1-4).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 14 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Discusses the prooemiun\n(introduction), which demonstrates how the introduction should be used in both\nepideictic and judicial speeches. Both have the main goal of signaling the end\nof the speech (Bk. 3 14:1-11).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 15 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Handles prejudicial\nattacks according to Aristotle which later on became part of Stasis\n(argumentation theory) which is \"determining the question at issue in a\ntrial\".<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-74h8-Jv6W5k/VZUUqcfozbI/AAAAAAAA7Ew/vDsV3MSggXQ/s1600/downl68oad%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"240\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-74h8-Jv6W5k/VZUUqcfozbI/AAAAAAAA7Ew/vDsV3MSggXQ/s320/downl68oad%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 16 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Di\u0113g\u0113sis or narration\nis discussed and demonstrates how one must work through an argument by using\nlogos. Narration differs in epideictic, judicial, and deliberative narratives.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 17 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Looks at the pistis or\nthe proof in an oration, and how it varies in each type of speech.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 18 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Erot\u0113sis, also known as\ninterrogation referred to asking and demanding responses in trials during\nAristotle's time. It is seen as, \"most opportune when an opponent has said\none thing and when if the right question is asked, an absurdity results\"\n(Bk. 3 19:1).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-WKctBXUqjhs/VZUU6FB3B2I/AAAAAAAA7E4/JBkEl-PLlCI/s1600/downlf1oad%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"380\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-WKctBXUqjhs/VZUU6FB3B2I/AAAAAAAA7E4/JBkEl-PLlCI/s400/downlf1oad%2B%25281%2529.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Chapter 19 <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\">Aristotle's final\nchapter in Book III discusses epilogues, which are the conclusion of speeches\nand must include four things: \"disposing the hearer favorably toward the\nspeaker and unfavorably to the opponent, amplifying and minimizing, moving the\nhearer into emotional reactions, and giving reminder of the speech's main\npoints\" (Bk. 3 19:1-4).<o:p></o:p></span></i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-BoUcDr-0iZE/VZQmuF70qUI/AAAAAAAA7EA/qDVENN26xJU/s1600/csimages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-BoUcDr-0iZE/VZQmuF70qUI/AAAAAAAA7EA/qDVENN26xJU/s1600/csimages.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ntu0AzWX_Tg/VZUVbsHf-mI/AAAAAAAA7FA/GbqMJQK2dn8/s1600/i7umages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ntu0AzWX_Tg/VZUVbsHf-mI/AAAAAAAA7FA/GbqMJQK2dn8/s1600/i7umages.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-zIW9tN0GZNU/VZUWCzH970I/AAAAAAAA7FQ/gAU0M5EXevg/s640/article-0-091241A60g00005DC-774_468x640.jpg\" width=\"468\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Reputations can come\ndown like a house of cards long after you are dead and gone. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rothschild built a reputation\nfor all his stooges before he unleashed them on the unsuspecting masses. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This blogsite has already\ndragged a lot of them by their nostrils all the way to China Town.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So you have now heard\nof ethos/ pathos / logos and proper timing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aristotle was NOT smart\nenough to understand team DYNAMICS - the way of the GURUKUL.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At sea we had ordinary people\nachieving extraordinary things &nbsp;.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHECK OUT FOR YOURSELF\nIF YOU LIKE THE ARISTOTLE WAY OR THE CAPTAINs &nbsp;WAY.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">YOU WILL NOTICE &nbsp;THAT ARISTOTLE IS STUDYING IN TH</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">E</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;NURSERY\nS</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">E</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">CTION OF THE SCHOOL , WHERE THE CAPTAIN IS THE PRINCIPAL</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; -<b> &nbsp;</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<b>EACH OF THE YELLOW COLORED <span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red;\">RITD</span> LINES IN THE POST ABOVE MERITS A POTENT 30 PAGE ESSAY.</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<b>Well well, what do the CHOOT management school pundits know ? &nbsp;</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tGV39mpkLc8/VZnwaMVQWwI/AAAAAAAA7Fk/pzBvUebHhy0/s1600/imaG5ges.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"263\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tGV39mpkLc8/VZnwaMVQWwI/AAAAAAAA7Fk/pzBvUebHhy0/s400/imaG5ges.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<b>IIM - what a joke !! &nbsp; &nbsp;</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<b>Wet nappy UKG babies thinking that they are PHDs on leadership tactics ? &nbsp;&nbsp;</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<b>Inventories are managed, humans must be lead by a leader with SPIRIT.</b><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-0KL4kOhB3R0/VZnwjbObpWI/AAAAAAAA7Fs/WaqT4aBTiK0/s1600/im3Hages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-0KL4kOhB3R0/VZnwjbObpWI/AAAAAAAA7Fs/WaqT4aBTiK0/s320/im3Hages.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<b><br /></b>\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I was once told by all my\nwell wishers NOT to join a company run by a Belgian Jew. &nbsp;Since at sea I was on a <b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">SELF EXPLORATORY\nmission </b>, I joined this company.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem with this\ncompany was that the technical bosses were ex-Indian navy slave mentality engine\nroom fitters who worked their way up via a loophole in the back door. . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These petty minded ex-400\nrupees per month salary ,Taran Taran type minions, thought small and cut corners\nto squeeze a cent . &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They could never\nthink of dinner with silverware and waiters in cummerband. &nbsp;All they could think of were ground nuts and\ntap water on the street side.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ui0U8hs27Jc/VZn1MT4u4DI/AAAAAAAA7GA/ecI42TAvL8k/s1600/imagy5es.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"257\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ui0U8hs27Jc/VZn1MT4u4DI/AAAAAAAA7GA/ecI42TAvL8k/s400/imagy5es.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I bloodied the noses and\nasses of all these minion Indians hour after hour because this Belgian Jew owner was my FAN - literally\nmy shit did NOT smell for him.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When I left this company they all held a party and got raving drunk.&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0935\u093f\u091a\u093f\u0924\u094d\u0930\u0938\u094d\u092b\u0941\u0930\u0926\u094d\u0930\u0924\u094d\u0928\u092e\u093e\u0932\u093e\u0915\u093f\u0930\u0940\u091f\u0902</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0909\u0926\u091e\u094d\u091a\u0926\u094d\u092d\u0941\u091c\u093e\u0935\u0932\u094d\u0932\u0930\u0940\u0926\u0943\u0936\u094d\u092f\u092e\u0942\u0932\u094b-</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u092f\u092e\u0947\u0915\u093e\u0915\u094d\u0937\u0930\u0902 \u0928\u093f\u0930\u094d\u092e\u0932\u0902 \u0928\u093f\u0930\u094d\u0935\u093f\u0915\u0932\u094d\u092a\u0902</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0917\u0941\u0923\u093e\u0924\u0940\u0924\u092e\u093e\u0928\u0928\u094d\u0926\u092e\u093e\u0915\u093e\u0930\u0936\u0942\u0928\u094d\u092f\u092e\u094d |</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u092a\u0930\u0902 \u092a\u093e\u0930\u092e\u094b\u0902\u0915\u093e\u0930\u092e\u093e\u092e\u094d\u0928\u093e\u092f\u0917\u0930\u094d\u092d\u092e\u094d</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0935\u0926\u0928\u094d\u0924\u093f \u092a\u094d\u0930\u0917\u0932\u094d\u092d\u0902 \u092a\u0941\u0930\u093e\u0923\u0902 \u0924\u092e\u0940\u0921\u0947 ||\u096d||</span><br />\n<br style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Roboto, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\" />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u091a\u093f\u0926\u093e\u0928\u0928\u094d\u0926\u0938\u093e\u0928\u094d\u0926\u094d\u0930\u093e\u092f \u0936\u093e\u0928\u094d\u0924\u093e\u092f \u0924\u0941\u092d\u094d\u092f\u0902</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0928\u092e\u094b \u0935\u093f\u0936\u094d\u0935\u0915\u0930\u094d\u0924\u094d\u0930\u0947 \u091a \u0939\u0930\u094d\u0924\u094d\u0930\u0947 \u091a \u0924\u0941\u092d\u094d\u092f\u092e\u094d |</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0928\u092e\u094b\u093d\u0928\u0928\u094d\u0924\u0932\u0940\u0932\u093e\u092f \u0915\u0948\u0935\u0932\u094d\u092f\u092d\u093e\u0938\u0947</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0928\u092e\u094b \u0935\u093f\u0936\u094d\u0935\u092c\u0940\u091c \u092a\u094d\u0930\u0938\u0940\u0926\u0947\u0936\u0938\u0942\u0928\u094b ||\u096e||</span><br />\n<br style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: Roboto, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\" />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0907\u092e\u0902 \u0938\u0941\u0938\u094d\u0924\u0935\u0902 \u092a\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0924\u0930\u0941\u0924\u094d\u0925\u093e\u092f \u092d\u0915\u094d\u0924\u094d\u092f\u093e</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u092a\u0920\u0947\u0926\u094d\u092f\u0938\u094d\u0924\u0941 \u092e\u0930\u094d\u0924\u094d\u092f\u094b \u0932\u092d\u0947\u0924\u094d\u0938\u0930\u094d\u0935\u0915\u093e\u092e\u093e\u0928\u094d |</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0917\u0923\u0947\u0936\u092a\u094d\u0930\u0938\u093e\u0926\u0947\u0928 \u0938\u093f\u0926\u094d\u0927\u094d\u092f\u0928\u094d\u0924\u093f \u0935\u093e\u091a\u094b</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: #333333; font-family: &quot;roboto&quot; , &quot;arial&quot; , sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 17px;\">\u0917\u0923\u0947\u0936\u0947 \u0935\u093f\u092d\u094c \u0926\u0941\u0930\u094d\u0932\u092d\u0902 \u0915\u093f\u0902 \u092a\u094d\u0930\u0938\u0928\u094d\u0928\u0947 ||\u096f||</span><br />\n<b><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Who appears pleasing with\nthe sounds of joyful swinging small bells across His body, Whose lotus-feet is\ntrembling to the dance of Tandav in rebellious ways, and Who has a\nsnake-garland shining over His belly.||1||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Whose face is resplendent\nhearing the sounds coming out from the strings of veena (music instrument), Who\nhas a resplendent trunk-stem and temple, Who has a shiny flow of juice from the\ntrunk-temple, and Who has a trickling garland of fragrant flowers with\nbumble-bees hovering around.||2||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Who is shining like the\nblood-red inner new shoots of the china rose (a.dahula) owing to the morning\nred light, Who has a large (long) belly, Who has a round belly, and Who has\none-elephant tusk.||3||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Who is adorned by colorful\nshining garland of diamonds and jewels, Who is adorned at the forehead by\nstreaks of diamond-like moon, Who is like the ornament of those without\nornaments, and Who is for the destruction of the world (at the end of\nKalpa).||4||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Who has elevating creeper\nlike hand, which is worth a sight, Whose forehead is moving to and fro and\nshining, and Who is served by the fan of shining beauty.||5||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise the leader of\nthe Gana of Rudra, Who is the son of Ishan (Shiv), Who has a shining and rough\ntongue, Who has yellowish corner (pupil) of the eyes, Who takes an incarnation\nfor mercy, comfort and benevolence, and Who is attained by the Yogi who sing\nHis praises.||6||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">I praise that Ganesha,\nWho is the beginning of the universe, Who is pure, Who is free from\ndifferences, Who is beyond the qualities, Who is pure bliss, Who is formless,\nWho is beyond everything, Who is OMkar, Who is the creator of illusions, and\nWhom eminent Purana sing.||7||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Salutations for\nGanesha, Who agglutinates happiness and bliss, Who is peaceful, Who creates and\ndestroys the world, Who has immeasurable sportivity (leela), Who is only light\nor enlightenment. O Ganesh, Who is the root of the world, Who is the son of\nShiv! Accept my salutes and be happy on me.||8||<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Those who study this\neulogy, having woken up in the morning, with devotion achieve all the desires\nin the mundane existence. They also attain Vaak-Siddhi (a power in which spoken\nwishes get fulfilled). When Ganesh is happy, then what can be difficult?\n(Nothing).||9||</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<span class=\"Apple-style-span\" style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><span class=\"Apple-style-span\" style=\"font-size: x-small;\"><br /><br /></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; BECAUSE DEEP INSIDE I GIVE THEM A TERRIFIC COMPLEX..<br /><br />IN THE HOLLYWOOD MOVIE \" THE FOREIGNER \"---<br /><br />JACKIE CHAN -- TAKES ON THE IRISH TERRORISTS WHO KILLED HIS DAUGHTER.<br /><br />EVERY TIME THE IRA GETS ROYALLY SCREWED BY JACKIE CHAN, THEY WOULD GET TOGETHER \u2013 AN EMERGENCY MEET -- TO DISCUSS HOW TO HANDLE HIM IN THE FUTURE..<br /><br />THE RESULT WAS ALWAYS&nbsp;<span style=\"color: red; font-size: medium;\"><b>\" FOOKING CHINAMAN \"..&nbsp;</b></span><br /><br />SAME WAY--<br /><br />EVER SINCE I ATTENDED SCHOOL, AND TILL I RETIRED FROM SEA -- THE TOP GUN WAS MY FAN ( MY SHIT DID NOT SMELL FOR HIM ) ,<br /><br />THE MIDDLE MANAGEMENT HATED ME LIKE THE PLAGUE ( THEY HATED MY GUTS )<br /><br />AND THE BOTTOM MANAGEMENT LOVED ME ( THEY KNEW I WAS BETTER THAN THE ENTIRE MIDDLE MANAGEMENT IN COMPETENCE AND THEY LOVED MY GUTS OF DEALING WITH THE HATERS WITH THE SWORD OF DAMOCLES SELF INFLICTED OVER MY HEAD ) ..<br /><br /><span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/blue-ocean-leadership-capt-ajit.html</span><br /><br />THE MIDDLE MANAGEMENT WOULD GET DRUNK ( ON SUNDAYS ) WHILE THEY DISCUSSED HOW TO SCREW ME -- AND THEN THE END RESULT WAS \"&nbsp;<span style=\"color: red; font-size: medium;\"><b>FUCKIN' COURT JESTER</b></span>&nbsp;\"<br /><br />MEANING --<br /><br />I WAS LIKE BIRBAL TO AKBAR -- THEY DONT HAVE TO LIKE ME--BUT SURELY THEY HAVE TO LUMP ME.<br /><br />\"PHHAKKIN' BADAKAYIL - TAKIN\u2019 LIPE TOO EAAJJY \"..<br /><br />TEE HEEEE .<br /><br /><span style=\"color: red;\">https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654</span><br /><br />I HAVE BEEN ASKED THIS QUESTION SEVERAL TIMES SINCE I STARTED BLOGGING -- IN YOUR PROFILE YOU HAVE SAID THAT YOU ARE A \"PARADOX LOVER\" --WHAT DO YOU MEAN BY THAT..</div>\n<div>\n<b style=\"color: blue;
